article: How to Cook Hard Boiled Eggs Without Cracking
intro: Eggs are tricky, and it can be hard to boil them without cracking the shells. When eggs are cold, they crack more easily upon exposure to hot water; they may also crack when they jumble into one another or settle at the bottom of the pot. In order to keep your eggs from breaking, you will need to handle them gently, boil them slowly, and keep a close eye on the temperature difference between the egg and the water.

steps.title: Add vinegar to the water.
steps.subtitle: Use one teaspoon of vinegar for each egg, and pour it directly into the water before you turn the heat on. Adding vinegar to the water helps the proteins in the egg white coagulate faster to plug any cracks that develop in the shell. This is a common problem, especially with eggs that are very cold.
sub-points: You can also wait to add vinegar when an egg cracks in the water. You may notice a bit of white fluid seeping from a cracked egg. Try to be quick here — if you add the vinegar to the water as soon as you notice a crack, the egg should still boil evenly.
If you don't add the vinegar in time, don't worry. The cracked egg should still boil fine, although it may not look perfect.
Be sparing. If you use too much, your eggs will taste and smell like vinegar.

steps.title: Store eggs in the refrigerator for up to five days.
steps.subtitle: The eggs are ready to eat as soon as you peel them. Store the leftover eggs in a sealed container, and cover them with a wet paper towel. Change the paper towel each day to keep the eggs from drying out. Eat the eggs within four to five days, before they go bad.
sub-points: You can also store the eggs in cold water. Change the water each day to keep the eggs from breaking down.

You can store hard-boiled eggs for several days before you crack and peel them. Keep in mind, however, that they tend to grow somewhat dry and rubbery. It's usually better to keep peeled eggs moist in the fridge than to leave the eggs unpeeled.
You can also store the eggs in cold water. Change the water each day to keep the eggs from breaking down.

You can store hard-boiled eggs for several days before you crack and peel them. Keep in mind, however, that they tend to grow somewhat dry and rubbery. It's usually better to keep peeled eggs moist in the fridge than to leave the eggs unpeeled.
